CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. ITO (Indium Tin Oxide)
2. PEDOT : PSS (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate))
3. MoO3 (Molybdenum Trioxide)
4. Al (Aluminum)
5. PC71BM (2,7-Polydiacetylene-alt-[2,2′-(2,2-diphenyl)-1,1′-binaphthyl]-5,5′-bis(2,2′-biphenyl))
6. PBDT-TDPP-S (Benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene-alt-[3-(2,2-diphenyl-diketopyrrolopyrrole)]-S side-chain polymer)

| Material Name |
| --- |
| ITO (Indium Tin Oxide) |
| PEDOT : PSS (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate)) |
| MoO3 (Molybdenum Trioxide) |
| Al (Aluminum) |
| PC71BM (2,7-Polydiacetylene-alt-[2,2′-(2,2-diphenyl)-1,1′-binaphthyl]-5,5′-bis(2,2′-biphenyl)) |
| PBDT-TDPP-S (Benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene-alt-[3-(2,2-diphenyl-diketopyrrolopyrrole)]-S side-chain polymer) |

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| ITO (Indium Tin Oxide) |
| PEDOT : PSS (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate)) |
| MoO3 (Molybdenum Trioxide) |
| Al (Aluminum) |
| PC71BM (2,7-Polydiacetylene-alt-[2,2′-(2,2-diphenyl)-1,1′-binaphthyl]-5,5′-bis(2,2′-biphenyl)) |
| PBDT-TDPP-S (Benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene-alt-[3-(2,2-diphenyl-diketopyrrolopyrrole)]-S side-chain polymer) |

The entities "ITO/PEDOT : PSS (40 nm)" and "active layer (varied thickness)" are not clear material names and have been removed. The entities "hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1" and "electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1" are not material names but rather properties of the materials. The entities "Figure S7" and "Table 4" are not material names but rather references to figures and tables in the document. The entities "highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers" and "highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs" are not material names but rather statements about the significance of the reported results. The entities "benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain" and "acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain" are not material names but rather descriptions of the chemical structure of PBDT-TDPP-S. The entities "donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain" and "acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain" are redundant with the previous entities and have been removed. The entities "corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones" are not material names but rather a comparison to other types of polymers. The entities "our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs" and "Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. )" are not material names but rather statements about the significance of the research and contact information for the authors.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide
2. PEDOT: PSS: PEDOT: PSS (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene): Poly(styrenesulfonate)
3. active layer: The material composed of PBDT-TDPP-S and PC71BM
4. varied thickness: Thickness of the active layer (PBDT-TDPP-S)
5. MoO3: Molybdenum Trioxide
6. Al: Aluminum (100 nm thick)
7. hole mobility: The mobility of holes in the active layer
8. electron mobility: The mobility of electrons in the active layer
9. Figure 4: A figure showing J-V characteristics of PBDT-TDPP-S devices
10. Figure S7: A figure showing the electron mobility of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend
11. Figure S8: A figure showing AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film
12. surface roughness: Roughness of the active layer surface
13. prethermal annealing: A thermal treatment process before the main annealing step
14. PBDT-TDPP-S: A novel conjugated polymer with a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in the main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in the side chain.
15. PC71BM: A fullerene derivative used as an acceptor material in the active layer.
16. PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency

The following entities do not clearly refer to "Property Name of material":

* ITO: Indium Tin Oxide
* PEDOT:PSS: PEDOT: PSS (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene): Poly(styrenesulfonate)
* MoO3: Molybdenum Trioxide
* Al: Aluminum (100 nm)
* Figure 4: A figure showing J-V characteristics of PBDT-TDPP-S devices
* Figure S7: A figure showing the electron mobility of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend
* Figure S8: A figure showing AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film
* PBDT-TDPP-S: A novel conjugated polymer with a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in the main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in the side chain.
* PC71BM: A fullerene derivative used as an acceptor material in the active layer.
* prethermal annealing: A thermal treatment process before the main annealing step
* PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency

The following entities are not properties of materials:

* The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C.
* The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition.
* It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing.
* The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance.
* To our best knowledge, the FF is the highest reported to date for side-chain D-A conjugated copolymers.
* The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89%.
* The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side-chain D-A conjugated copolymers based single BHJ PSCs, which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main-chain D-A polymer-based ones.
* Our work presented a new promising side-chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high-performance PSCs.
* Corresponding Author *E-mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com (W.Z. ); hbwu @ scut.edu.cn (H.W. ); yongcao @ scut.edu.cn (Y.C. ).

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones.
